Instructions.text: While Concentration Ratio deals with quantity, Enrichment Ratio is a quick dive into the quality of your Concentrate. It gives you a ratio between the amount of precious metal going in and the amount of precious metal going out of the system.
Enrichment Ratio can be calculated by dividing a metal grade on the Concentrate stream by the grade of the same metal in the Feed stream.
Before we start, take a look at the Feed stream and tell me what is the Cu grade entering the flotation stage.
Great job. Now set the air flow of the flotation stage to 1 and the froth to -20. What is the Cu grade going out of the system (Concentrate Stream)?

The magical act of turning 1% Cu into 5% Cu is called Concentration process, also known as Beneficiation. Flotation is a very common form of Concentration, which can bring the metal grade from less than 1% up to about 30%.
In order to enrich the metal content from 30% Cu to 100% Cu, other processes like filtration and smelting are involved but perhaps they deserve their own educational games.

Bringing the metal content from 0% to 100% is called Enrichment and we can see how good we are at enriching metals by calculating the Enrichment Ratio using the formula:

 Enrichment ratio =
Concentrate Metal % / Feed Metal %

Let's try! In a flotation process where the precious metal is nickel, and the Feed Ni % is 2 while the Concentrate Ni % is 6, what would be the Enrichment Ratio?

 Enrichment ratio =
Concentrate Metal % / Feed Metal %

Now check the Cu grade in the Feed and Concentrate streams with the air at 1 and the froth at -20. What is the Enrichment Ratio of this cell?n
 Enrichment ratio =
Concentrate Metal % / Feed Metal %

Correct. Although Enrichment Ratio gives us a quick look into the relationship of the metal grades in the system, it does not take quantity into consideration, unlike metal recovery. We are going to learn how to correlate quantity and quality in the next lessons.
